questions.explanation: In Hofstede's cultural dimensions framework, Malaysia and the Philippines are the classic examples of countries high in Power Distance, meaning there is widespread acceptance of hierarchical authority and unequal distribution of power. Greece and Japan are associated with high Uncertainty Avoidance, Japan and Hungary with high Masculinity, and China and South Korea with high Long-term Orientation.

questions.section: Four Common Attributions for Achievement Outcomes
questions.explanation: In Weiner's attribution theory, effort is classified as unstable because the amount of effort a person exerts can vary from situation to situation. This contrasts with ability, which is considered stable because it is perceived as relatively fixed over time. Effort is also unique among the four common attributions as the only one classified as controllable.

rows: Degree to which less powerful members accept unequal power distribution
Degree to which individuals are integrated into groups
Distribution of emotional roles between genders; achievement vs. quality of life
Degree to which a society tolerates ambiguity and uncertainty
Focus on future rewards (thrift, perseverance) vs. past and present (tradition, fulfilling social obligations)
Degree to which a society allows gratification of basic human desires
questions.explanation: Greece and Portugal score high on Uncertainty Avoidance, meaning these societies have low tolerance for ambiguity and uncertainty, preferring strict rules and structured situations. This is distinct from Power Distance (Malaysia, Philippines), Masculinity (Japan, Hungary), or Long-Term Orientation (China, Japan).

rows: Comfortable with intimacy and autonomy. Trusting, able to depend on others and allow others to depend on them. Associated with the best relationship outcomes.
Desire for extreme closeness and fear of rejection. Overly dependent, jealous, clingy. Self-worth contingent on partner's approval. Corresponds to anxious-ambivalent infant attachment.
Desire for intimacy coupled with fear of rejection and distrust. Avoidance of close relationships due to fear of being hurt. Often associated with history of trauma or loss.
questions.correct_value: Compulsive self-reliance. Denial of attachment needs. Emotional distance. View close relationships as unimportant. Corresponds to avoidant infant attachment.
options: Desire for intimacy coupled with fear of rejection and distrust. Avoidance of close relationships due to fear of being hurt. Often associated with history of trauma or loss.
Desire for extreme closeness and fear of rejection. Overly dependent, jealous, clingy. Self-worth contingent on partner's approval. Corresponds to anxious-ambivalent infant attachment.
Compulsive self-reliance. Denial of attachment needs. Emotional distance. View close relationships as unimportant. Corresponds to avoidant infant attachment.
Comfortable with intimacy and autonomy. Trusting, able to depend on others and allow others to depend on them. Associated with the best relationship outcomes.
questions.explanation: The Dismissing-Avoidant style is characterized by a positive model of self but a negative model of others, leading to compulsive self-reliance and denial of attachment needs. This is easily confused with the Fearful-Avoidant style, which also involves avoidance of close relationships but stems from a negative model of both self and others (fear of being hurt), rather than viewing relationships as unimportant. Dismissing-Avoidant corresponds to avoidant infant attachment in Ainsworth's classification.

In the Elaboration Likelihood Model, attitude change via the peripheral route is temporary and easily reversed because it is based on superficial cues (e.g., source attractiveness or expertise) rather than deep processing of argument quality. This contrasts with the central route, which produces durable attitude change that is resistant to counter-persuasion.

rows: The construct itself differs across cultures
Intelligence tests that emphasize verbal ability disadvantage those from oral traditions
The assessment method produces different effects across cultures
Individual items function differently across groups
Vocabulary items referencing culturally specific objects or experiences
questions.correct_value: Cultures that discourage self-disclosure may underperform on interview-based assessments
options: Vocabulary items referencing culturally specific objects or experiences
Intelligence tests that emphasize verbal ability disadvantage those from oral traditions
Cultures that discourage self-disclosure may underperform on interview-based assessments
Test instructions that are more familiar to certain cultural groups than others
questions.explanation: Method bias occurs when the assessment procedure or format itself produces differential effects across cultural groups. An interview-based assessment disadvantaging cultures that discourage self-disclosure is an example of how the method (interview format), rather than the construct or individual items, creates bias. This is distinct from construct bias (the underlying construct differs across cultures) and item bias (specific items function differently across groups).

rows: Consistency between cognitions, especially after counterattitudinal behavior
Proposes that dissonance can be reduced by affirming an unrelated important value rather than changing the inconsistent cognition
questions.correct_value: Consistency between attitude toward a source and attitude toward the position they advocate
options: Consistency between attitude toward a source and attitude toward the position they advocate
Consistency between cognitions, especially after counterattitudinal behavior
Proposes that dissonance can be reduced by affirming an unrelated important value rather than changing the inconsistent cognition
questions.explanation: Congruity Theory, proposed by Osgood & Tannenbaum (1955), specifically addresses the consistency between one's attitude toward a communicator (source) and one's attitude toward the position that source advocates. This distinguishes it from Balance Theory (which focuses on triadic P-O-X relationships) and Cognitive Dissonance (which focuses on consistency between cognitions after counterattitudinal behavior).

rows: People change behavior to match group norms
Less effort in groups when individual effort is not identifiable
questions.correct_value: 65% obeyed authority to maximum shock level
options: 65% obeyed authority to maximum shock level
People change behavior to match group norms
questions.explanation: Milgram's classic obedience study found that approximately 65% of participants administered what they believed to be the maximum (450-volt) shock level when instructed by an authority figure. This specific percentage is a highly testable fact and is often confused with other group influence findings.

questions.section: Summary Table: Key Identity Models Compared
rows: Abandonment of racism; defining non-racist White identity
options: Abandonment of racism; defining non-racist White identity
questions.explanation: Berry's Acculturation Model is a two-dimensional framework that identifies four acculturation strategies based on two independent dimensions (maintenance of heritage culture and participation in the host culture): integration, assimilation, separation, and marginalization. This distinguishes it from linear stage models by allowing for multiple simultaneous orientations toward both cultures.

rows: Obliviousness to one's own racial identity and to the significance of race. Naive curiosity about or fear of people of color. Satisfaction with the racial status quo.

Resolution of Disintegration anxiety through idealization of one's own group and intolerance of other groups. Belief that White superiority is justified. May be triggered by a negative interracial encounter.
questions.correct_value: First acknowledgment of White privilege. Moral dilemma between loyalty to one's White group and a desire for non-racist ideals. Feelings of guilt, shame, and anxiety.
options: Resolution of Disintegration anxiety through idealization of one's own group and intolerance of other groups. Belief that White superiority is justified. May be triggered by a negative interracial encounter.
First acknowledgment of White privilege. Moral dilemma between loyalty to one's White group and a desire for non-racist ideals. Feelings of guilt, shame, and anxiety.
Obliviousness to one's own racial identity and to the significance of race. Naive curiosity about or fear of people of color. Satisfaction with the racial status quo.
Intellectual acceptance of one's own Whiteness and recognition of the moral responsibility of being White. Active seeking of a non-racist White identity.
questions.explanation: The Disintegration status is characterized by the first acknowledgment of White privilege, creating a moral dilemma between loyalty to one's White group and non-racist ideals, resulting in feelings of guilt, shame, and anxiety. This is distinct from Contact (obliviousness to race), Reintegration (resolution through idealization of Whiteness), and later statuses involving active pursuit of a non-racist identity.

In Kelley's Covariation Model, an internal (person) attribution is made when consensus is Low, distinctiveness is Low, and consistency is High. Low distinctiveness means the person responds the same way across many different stimuli (e.g., 'She laughs at everything'), which signals that the cause is something about the person rather than the stimulus or the situation.

rows: Explicit derogatory verbal or nonverbal attacks meant to hurt. Most similar to traditional discrimination.
Using a racial slur; deliberately serving a White customer before a customer of color.
Communications that convey rudeness, insensitivity, or demean a person's heritage or identity. Often outside the perpetrator's awareness.
Asking an Asian American "Where are you really from?"; telling a person of color "You are so articulate."
"I don't see color"; "When I look at you, I see a human being, not a Black person."
questions.correct_value: Communications that exclude, negate, or nullify the psychological thoughts, feelings, or experiential reality of certain groups.
options: Communications that convey rudeness, insensitivity, or demean a person's heritage or identity. Often outside the perpetrator's awareness.
Communications that exclude, negate, or nullify the psychological thoughts, feelings, or experiential reality of certain groups.
Explicit derogatory verbal or nonverbal attacks meant to hurt. Most similar to traditional discrimination.
Subtle communications that reinforce stereotypes by attributing success to external factors rather than individual ability.
questions.explanation: Microinvalidations are defined as communications that exclude, negate, or nullify the psychological thoughts, feelings, or experiential reality of certain groups. This is distinct from microinsults (which convey rudeness or demean identity) and microassaults (which are explicit, deliberate attacks). The key distinguishing feature of microinvalidations is the negation or dismissal of a person's lived experience, as illustrated by statements like 'I don't see color.'

rows: Seeks closeness but fears rejection; clingy
Self-reliant; avoids closeness; denies need for others
Desires closeness but fears it; distrustful
questions.explanation: The Dismissing-Avoidant attachment style is characterized by a positive model of self (high self-worth, self-reliance) but a negative model of others (viewing others as unreliable or untrustworthy), which leads to avoidance of closeness and denial of the need for relationships. This is easily confused with the Fearful-Avoidant style, which also has a negative model of others but differs in having a negative model of self as well.

rows: Relinquishing one's heritage culture in favor of adopting the host culture. The individual seeks daily interaction with other cultures and does not wish to maintain their cultural identity.
Maintaining one's heritage culture while avoiding interaction with the larger society. When imposed by the dominant group, this is called segregation .
Neither maintaining one's heritage culture nor adopting the host culture. Often associated with the highest levels of acculturative stress and poorest psychological adjustment.
questions.correct_value: Maintaining one's heritage culture while also participating in the larger society. Generally associated with the best psychological outcomes and lowest acculturative stress.
options: Neither maintaining one's heritage culture nor adopting the host culture. Often associated with the highest levels of acculturative stress and poorest psychological adjustment.
Maintaining one's heritage culture while also participating in the larger society. Generally associated with the best psychological outcomes and lowest acculturative stress.
Maintaining one's heritage culture while avoiding interaction with the larger society. When imposed by the dominant group, this is called segregation .
Relinquishing one's heritage culture in favor of adopting the host culture. The individual seeks daily interaction with other cultures and does not wish to maintain their cultural identity.
questions.explanation: Integration involves maintaining one's heritage culture while also participating in the host culture (Yes/Yes). Research by Berry consistently shows that integration is associated with the best psychological outcomes and lowest acculturative stress, distinguishing it from separation (which avoids the host culture) and assimilation (which abandons the heritage culture).

The interdependent self prioritizes other-focused emotions such as shame and empathy, which serve to maintain social harmony and group cohesion. This contrasts with the independent self, which prioritizes ego-focused emotions like pride and anger that emphasize individual agency and self-assertion.

rows: Conformity increases up to about 3-5 members, then plateaus.
Greater ambiguity increases conformity (informational influence is stronger).
Higher cohesion increases conformity (normative influence is stronger).
Conformity is higher when responses are public.
Collectivistic cultures show higher conformity rates than individualistic cultures.
Lower-status individuals conform more to higher-status group members.
questions.correct_value: A single dissenter dramatically reduces conformity, even if the dissenter gives a different wrong answer.
options: Conformity increases linearly with each additional dissenter in the group.
A single dissenter dramatically reduces conformity, even if the dissenter gives a different wrong answer.
A dissenter only reduces conformity when they provide the correct answer.
Conformity is unaffected by dissenters as long as the majority remains consistent.
questions.explanation: Asch's classic conformity experiments demonstrated that the presence of even a single dissenter — regardless of whether that dissenter gave the correct answer or a different incorrect answer — dramatically reduced participants' conformity to the group's wrong answer. This is a highly testable finding because examinees often mistakenly assume the dissenter must provide the correct answer to break conformity.

The Storming stage is characterized by conflict, which manifests as disagreements, power struggles, and resistance among group members. This is distinct from the Forming stage (polite, tentative behavior), the Norming stage (cooperation and trust), and the Adjourning stage (closure and reflection).

In Milgram's obedience studies, when two confederates rebelled (refused to continue), the obedience rate dropped to only 10%. This demonstrates the powerful effect of social support for disobedience. This is often confused with the 21% rate (experimenter absent) or the 0% rate (two experimenters disagree), but the rebel confederates condition specifically yielded 10% obedience.

questions.section: Phase II: Defining a Non-Racist White Identity
rows: Active search for an accurate understanding of racism and Whiteness. Seeks to replace myths and stereotypes with accurate information. Emotional processing of what it means to be White.

Informed, positive White identity that is non-racist. Values diversity, actively seeks cross-racial interactions, and works against oppression. Ongoing process of refinement rather than a fixed endpoint.
questions.correct_value: First status of positive White identity. Intellectual acceptance of racial differences. May attempt to "help" people of color assimilate to White standards. Understanding remains largely cognitive rather than affective.
options: Active search for an accurate understanding of racism and Whiteness. Seeks to replace myths and stereotypes with accurate information. Emotional processing of what it means to be White.

First status of positive White identity. Intellectual acceptance of racial differences. May attempt to "help" people of color assimilate to White standards. Understanding remains largely cognitive rather than affective.

Informed, positive White identity that is non-racist. Values diversity, actively seeks cross-racial interactions, and works against oppression. Ongoing process of refinement rather than a fixed endpoint.

Abandonment of racist identity accompanied by guilt and shame. May attempt to distance from White culture and over-identify with people of color. Marked by emotional upheaval rather than cognitive understanding.
questions.explanation: Pseudo-Independence is the first status in Helms's Phase II (defining a non-racist White identity). It is characterized by an intellectual—but not yet affective—acceptance of racial differences, and individuals at this status may still inadvertently apply White norms by trying to 'help' people of color conform to White standards. This distinguishes it from Immersion-Emersion (active emotional processing and myth replacement) and Autonomy (internalized non-racist identity with active anti-oppression work).

In Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love, fatuous love is characterized by passion and commitment but without intimacy. This distinguishes it from romantic love (intimacy + passion), companionate love (intimacy + commitment), and empty love (commitment only). Fatuous love is considered 'foolish' because commitment is made on the basis of passion alone, without the stabilizing element of intimacy.

rows: People derive self-esteem from group memberships. They enhance self-esteem by favoring their ingroup over outgroups, even in minimal group paradigm conditions.
Frustration-aggression displaced onto weaker, available outgroups. Prejudice increases during economic downturns.
Certain personality characteristics (rigidity, conventionalism, submission to authority) predispose individuals to prejudice.
Prejudice is learned through modeling, reinforcement, and cultural transmission.
questions.correct_value: Prejudice arises from competition between groups for scarce resources. Demonstrated in the Robbers Cave experiment.
options: Frustration-aggression displaced onto weaker, available outgroups. Prejudice increases during economic downturns.
Prejudice arises from competition between groups for scarce resources. Demonstrated in the Robbers Cave experiment.
People derive self-esteem from group memberships. They enhance self-esteem by favoring their ingroup over outgroups, even in minimal group paradigm conditions.
Prejudice is learned through modeling, reinforcement, and cultural transmission.
questions.explanation: Realistic Conflict Theory, proposed by Sherif, holds that prejudice stems from intergroup competition over limited resources. This was famously demonstrated in the Robbers Cave experiment, where boys at a summer camp developed hostility toward the outgroup when placed in competitive situations. This is distinct from Scapegoat Theory (displaced frustration) and Social Identity Theory (self-esteem through group membership).

Fatuous Love in Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love is characterized by Passion and Commitment but without Intimacy. This distinguishes it from Romantic Love (Intimacy + Passion, no Commitment) and Companionate Love (Intimacy + Commitment, no Passion). The combination of passion and commitment without the deeper emotional bond of intimacy defines Fatuous Love as a 'whirlwind' type of love.

rows: Assuming the group's decisions are ethically correct
Viewing opponents as weak, evil, or stupid
Direct pressure to conform on members who express disagreement
Members who protect the group from dissenting information
options: Assuming the group's decisions are ethically correct
Members who protect the group from dissenting information
questions.explanation: The 'Illusion of unanimity' symptom of groupthink refers to the false perception that everyone agrees with the group's decision, specifically because silence is interpreted as consent. This is easily confused with 'self-censorship' (members withholding dissenting views), but the key distinction is that illusion of unanimity describes the group's misinterpretation of silence, while self-censorship describes the individual's decision to remain silent.

rows: Do other people behave this way toward the same stimulus?
Only this person laughs at the comedian
Does this person behave this way toward other stimuli?
This person laughs only at this comedian
Does this person behave this way at other times/situations?
This person always laughs at this comedian
This person laughed only this one time
questions.correct_value: This person laughs at all comedians
options: Only this person laughs at the comedian
This person laughs at all comedians
This person laughed only this one time
This person laughs only at this comedian
questions.explanation: Low distinctiveness means the person does NOT distinguish between stimuli — they behave the same way toward many different stimuli. Therefore, the person laughs at all comedians (not just this one), indicating nothing distinctive about this particular comedian in eliciting the behavior.

rows: Adopt host culture at the expense of heritage culture
Maintain heritage culture while avoiding engagement with host culture
Reject both heritage and host cultures; associated with poorest psychological outcomes
questions.correct_value: Maintain heritage culture while also engaging with host culture; generally associated with best psychological outcomes
options: Adopt host culture at the expense of heritage culture
Maintain heritage culture while also engaging with host culture; generally associated with best psychological outcomes
Reject both heritage and host cultures; associated with poorest psychological outcomes
Maintain heritage culture while avoiding engagement with host culture
questions.explanation: Integration involves maintaining one's heritage culture while simultaneously engaging with the host culture (Yes/Yes). Research consistently shows that integration is associated with the best psychological outcomes among the four acculturation strategies, distinguishing it from assimilation (which abandons the heritage culture), separation (which avoids the host culture), and marginalization (which rejects both).

rows: Only asking questions that support a hypothesis
"I knew the client would drop out"
Choosing different treatments based on how risks are described
options: Only asking questions that support a hypothesis
questions.explanation: The representativeness heuristic involves judging likelihood based on how similar something is to a prototype, which leads people to ignore base rate information. For example, a clinician might diagnose a rare disorder because the client's presentation closely matches the prototype, while failing to consider how uncommon that disorder actually is in the population.

rows: Start with a small request, then escalate to the larger target request
Start with an unreasonably large request (that will be refused), then retreat to the target request
Get agreement to an attractive deal, then reveal hidden costs or change the terms
Before the person decides, sweeten the deal by adding bonuses or reducing the price
questions.explanation: The door-in-the-face technique works on the principle of reciprocity — specifically reciprocal concessions. When the requester 'retreats' from a large request to a smaller one, the target feels obligated to reciprocate the concession by agreeing to the smaller request. This is commonly confused with commitment & consistency, which underlies the foot-in-the-door and lowball techniques.
